definitions.definition: to take somebody/something in your hand suddenly and using force

examples.text: She tried to seize the gun from him.
He seized her by the arm.
He seized the book from her hand.
The wrestlers try to seize hold of each other.

definitions.definition: to take control of a place or situation, often suddenly and violently

examples.text: They seized the airport in a surprise attack.
The army has **seized control of** the country.
He **seized power** in a military coup.
The men were seized as they left the building.
He was immediately seized and thrown into prison.
A Briton has been seized by border guards and jailed for eight years.

definitions.definition: to take illegal or stolen goods away from somebody

examples.text: A large quantity of drugs was seized during the raid.
We have the legal right to seize his property.

definitions.definition: to be quick to make use of a chance, an opportunity, etc.
definitions.sensetop: seize a chance, an opportunity, the initiative, etc.

examples.text: The party **seized** the initiative **with both hands** *(= quickly and with enthusiasm)*.
She promptly seized the opportunity his absence gave her.

definitions.definition: to affect somebody suddenly and deeply
if a machine seizes, it no longer works because the parts are stuck and cannot move
definitions.labels: (North American English)British and North American English

definitions.definition: if a part of your body seizes, you are unable to move it easily and it is often painful
definitions.labels: (North American English)British and North American English

wordOrigin: Middle English: from Old French seizir ‘give seisin (possession of land)’, from medieval Latin sacire, in the phrase ad proprium sacire ‘claim as one's own’, from a Germanic base meaning ‘procedure’.
